review.title: Epistemic Logic with Functional Dependency Operator
review.abstract: Epistemic logic with non-standard knowledge operators, especially the "knowing-value" operator, has recently gathered much attention. With the "knowing-value" operator, we can express knowledge of individual variables, but not of the relations between them in general. In this paper, we propose a new operator Kf to express knowledge of the functional dependencies between variables. The semantics of this Kf operator uses a function domain which imposes a constraint on what counts as a functional dependency relation. By adjusting this function domain, different interesting logics arise, and in this paper we axiomatize three such logics in a single agent setting. Then we show how these three logics can be unified by allowing the function domain to vary relative to different agents and possible worlds. A multiagent axiomatization is given in this case.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 6.02 048v 1 [cs.A I] Epistemic logic with non-standard knowledge operators, especially the "worth knowing" operator, has received a lot of attention lately. By using the "worth knowing" operator, we can express knowledge of individual variables, but not of the relationships between them in general. In this paper, we propose a new operator Kf to express knowledge of the functional dependencies between variables. The semantics of this Kf operator uses a functional range that imposes a limitation on what counts as a functional dependency relationship. Adapting this functional range results in various interesting logics, and in this essay we axiomatize three such logics in a single agent setting. Then, we show how these three logics can be unified by varying the functional domain relative to different agents and possible worlds. In this case, a multi-agomatization is given.
